The video game industry makes more money that CD's, magazines/books, DVD's and even Hollywood movies. Clearly a lot of people play video games and in this day and age of cell phones, not only "kids" but many adults, parents, even grandparents play video games. I found this video to be really insightful and it provides an interesting perceptions of video games. I also found the "too much of everything" part to be extremely relevant to the elements presented in your video. I personally find that games tend to take the blame for issues that arise from misuse or abuse of gaming features or contents. Just like you stated, if someone dies from water toxicity, we would not start claiming that water is dangerous for health and yet quite a lot of people tend to place a lot of focus on the negative aspects of video games while simply overlooking the positive impacts that video games may have on social as well as mental health. I believe that for a lot of things we need to focus on the positive more than just berating anything simply for the sake of standing out or trying to seem like a special snowflake who does not follow current trends. All the positive aspects highlighted in your video would hopefully encourage a more welcoming perspective on video games. I just want to say kudos for this video and keep up the good work to change the mindset of our society on video games. #gaminglife

I hate when people say that video games make people violent. That is simply untrue. Anyone who is smarter than a 2 year old will know that it's just a game and you shouldn't shoot people in real life. And even if they DID turn violent, you can't just point a finger at the game itself, because things like mental conditions could have caused such a reaction. On top of this, that sort of thing happening is still extremely rare.

So please, don't blame all video games, and video games alone for "causing violence", because it's not the game's fault. It's the person playing it. It's like saying "all cars are bad because people don't know how to drive and crash them". It just doesn't make sense.

I don't appreciate the cognitive affect as much as others. I find it a very good way to relieve stress. My stress response used to be very poor with video games, but other the years I've learned to relax and have fun more. It gives me something to focus my attention on and during that I can observe the tension and allow it to drop, helping me attain a more relaxed focus on the game.
Plus the after affects are pretty cool. There's a pleasant dissociative feeling probably from a reduction in default mode network (DMN) activity. Let me tell you one thing. I stopped gaming about two years ago. Before 2 years, I used to play all types of games. And those days were amazing for my academics. My friends used to call me a computer because of my memory skills and the very high marks that I earn in a test. But after that, my Pc broke down and my ps2 started getting slow. Unfortunately, my parents didn't fix it for me. So I started to spend my days without games. The result was a drastic decrease in my memory and the speed of learning new concepts. I didn't become so bad. But I felt a little bit slow in everything. I could really feel it. I needed more time to focus and learn. However I still remained the best student of my class. But I wasn't satisfied within myself. It's like going to an i3 from an i7. But now I bought a ps4 and back into the action. Within just one week, I have experience a lot of improvements. I feel so much alive now. So, yeah, for my experience, gaming does a lot to your brain. But I won't recommend playing for a whole day.

I actually researched this topic for a class once, only it was about the effects of playing video games on Alzheimer's patients.  The results were that it actually increased memory and slightly increased coordination.  However, I have also found that playing too many video games can have some negative results as well.  The most common complaint was that when students play video games in excess of an hour per day (7-10 hours a week) they may be sacrificing valuable study and homework time and academics would take the hit.  It's important to maintain a healthy balance of video gaming because there are some benefits and advantages to playing video games.  This is why there are new "brain games" that have been created, such as; Lumosity.  Lumosity allows people to play games for a short duration of time (10-15 minutes a day), which increases focus, coordination, and memory, and without it being excessive.

One of the best ways to get a balance of video games and outside time is this(I have this so, yeah):
1.Have two accounts on you computer.
2. Make one and 'administrator' and one a 'child'.
3. Get someone else(probably should be someone you live with) to put a password on the administrator account.
4. Get the person who knows the password to put time limits(Like a schedule, I can be on from about 6 am, then get off and 9-9;30am, then at 11;30-12;30-lunch, etc.) on the child account.
5. Only ever use the child account.
This way it locks you out every two hours or so, you have a break for lunch, and the best way to avoid just getting on another device is, have the same person who has the admin account to tell you off for not going outside. And if you ABSOLUTELY need more time, using the password, the admin can give you up to 4 hours more time. So, if you have,say, an assignment due at like midnight that you haven't started, you can finish it asap. I HIGHLY recommend this method. I am serious.

Don't even mention the "education games". Those are garbage and don't even educate. Scientific experiments even back this up. There's a website (I don't remember the name) that claims to exercise your brain with games of sorts, and experiments show that people that use it on a regular basis show improvement over time...at that specific game and nothing else. It did not actually make them any smarter for any other purpose.

Contrast this with actual games; they are not asking direct academic questions, but rather asking you to solve various scenarios. This invokes real problem-solving skills, almost as if they could apply in real life. There are plenty of very real skills that are used in video games, many of them useful for real life.

It's the difference between teaching you to succeed academically and teaching you to succeed in highly-unusual but more practical settings. Sure, the latter is spotty at best, but when applied correctly, really does help. The former won't be useful once you graduate.

For a person my age at that time those games were brutally hard for me, so it took me years to complete them and I played a decent hours each day. I learned how to explore, how to remember paths I need to back track, I learned to dare to try crazy things, I learned to control my fears, to think out of the box and most importantly, I learned to never let go! Thank you lara croft for what you taught me.

"Action Video Games Make Dyslexic Children Read Better"  That's the title of the research!  It's such a ridiculously poorly thought out title.  The other articles from that issue of Current Biology are much more scientific sounding (http://www.cell.com/current-biology/issue?pii=S0960-9822%2813%29X0006-5 - midway down under reports.)  The title for this one reminds me of "The Derek Zoolander School for Kids Who Can't Read Good and Want to Do Other Stuff Good Too"  :D

Video games are becoming increasingly helpful to society. It seems that from their beginning, all sorts of video games have been improving from many innovations to their design. The first games were made with simple goals for the competitive motives of the game user. Those games were solely used for entertainment purposes, though they had other unintentional benefits as well. For example, some of the gamers who played even the most simple of the games would show heightened abilities in reflexes, as well as some cognitive functions. As these games have evolved, so have their effects, and purposes. With games evoking more change in people with their evolution, it becomes important to question the potential for games to be used for many purposes. In this video, video games are not looked at as only useful for entertainment. The concern here is the effect video games may have on the mind and improvement of cognition in certain areas. Video games used in this way will be more based upon principles of learning, while still maintaining the elements of entertainment characteristic of those games. Now looking at games in this way, we are equipped with a very flexible tool which has endless possibilities. If one is bored, they can use video games for their own entertainment for that moment. If someone is not efficient in memory, they can put video games to use by playing them and letting the games naturally improve their cognition in areas of the brain which may facilitate memory. Even if one is hoping to become more physically in shape, games can be a solution. In the generation of video game consoles like the Wii, and Kinect, people may once again use games as a tool to provide them with an intricate exercise machine which directs the user through the workout, while also giving distinct data and analysis of specific bodily functions fluctuating throughout the process.
With all these possibilities, it is important that more people take the initiative to look outside the box, and see games in a different light. Instead of believing games as being only suitable for entertainment, people should support a more well rounded view of these video games so that more imaginative ways of using them could be thought of. If more people are able to do this, more innovate creations are made, which gives society even more tools to use for different situations and issues for which video games have the potential for application.When this happens, the society as a whole receives an ever increasing advantage only limited to the imagination. Therefore, videos such as these need to be more supported throughout the world and taken more into consideration than they usually are. A change like this could have lasting effects on humanity, helping in ways never before thought possible. The advantages gamers have in brain power are only a portion of the potential for effectiveness video games currently have. This potential will continue to increase in the future. Whether this potential is put in to use effectively, is up to the people. This is why awareness in the wide variety of ways to utilize games should be more widespread than it is currently. Video games are currently items of high value for change in society, and will be for many generations to come. What do you think the future uses for video games may be in the future and how will it effect humanity overall?

-ASU Student for English 101 Steph

This comment section sheds some insight on video games and the way people view them. I think that most video games are looked at in a certain way which amplifies their more negative, gruesome characteristic and tend to overshadow the benefits. The reactions to the video partially reflects this. Many of the comments for this video seem to express a bit of surprise at the fact that anything may be beneficial from video games. Since the view of video games has been so one sided for so long, it may make it harder to believe that there is another side of the story which is not being demonstrated as much as the other. In essence, I agree that video games has benefits and I have experienced some of the benefits for myself in my lifetime. One of the most powerful benefits I have received from gaming is the enhancement of my learning abilities and my ability to make clear connections between certain events and facts. These two fundamental abilities help me to solve many problems in the real world. The benefits of video games should be looked into more deeply to give balance to the subject.

A few games do teach you things without being "kid-ish" education games. Eternal Sonata taught me a bit about music appreciation, the Polish Revolution and about the life and musical works of it's main character: Fredrick Chopin.

Assassin's Creed never fails to bring a good history lesson.

To The Moon explained a bit about medicine and teaches you a lot about a certain mental illness (and MY GOD is it ever a sad story v_v )

America's Army, being a game that was created by the US military for training and recruiting purposes, actually had accurate depictions of military field medicine techniques in it. There has been at least one recorded instance of a civilian saving someone's life by imitating the medical techniques depicted in that game.

I'm a gamer and my grades are terrible. But this shows me something that was really extrodinary and scientific. It tells me that video games are actually good for you! Everything the guy said in the vid really inspired me. My mom always tell me that "Games are bad for you!". But I didn't care about it. When I was in elementary school, my grades are the worst. My mom always hit me, my uncle keeps saying things I don't understand. But that didn't stop me from playing video games. Believe me, it helps alot. Some games are educational, some are puzzle and based on what strategy you use. When middle school came, I became the smartest in my class. My grades went higher and I was happy for myself. Even though I played more and more games, it made me smart. I solved a puzzle in just seconds, I can do many kinds of strategy which really helps me when it comes to strategy based video games. Educational games are really important. It help me by learning some history and facts that I don't even know. History classes are boresome and tiresome, but by playing some educational games was really easy to answer all the question about history this, history that. But the most greatest thing ever made in video game history are the RPG video games. It gives you life lessons that can be really sad, great, cool and you can get inspired by what the game has to say to you. There's always hope for us, gamers out there. Never stop playing games. Even our parents reject that, you still can play video games. We're gamers for life. Never forget that!

I remember when I was around 9 and I was not focusing on anything, than my own teacher recommended me to play video game such as Legend of Zelda, and he also recommended me to play the first StarCraft (was on the N64). Now I'm in high school and I focus more than most of kids who don't play video games

Stay away from games that have you "grind", those types will turn you brain-dead within a week or so if you get addicted. To "grind" in a video game means you do the same action over and over again to get a different end-result, much like dice rolling. Stay away from these type of games at all costs. Especially if they are advertised as "free to play", they will take advantage of why a game is addictive and will get you to spend more money than you needed. This is why there is a slang called "pay to win" within the online gaming community.

I'm not sure about video games making people smarter but I'm positive video games can make people more creative.  It's like when I was a kid I rarely read books.  Now, I read all the time and as a result I've become very adept at writing well structured stories.

With a good video game I, like many other people, can feel like I'm in a story like I did when I played Red Dead Redemption.  The old western setting was very atmospheric that I felt like I was taken back in time.  I can feel strong emotions like fear when playing Amnesia: The Dark Descent.  Games like Minecraft require creativity to be fun at all.  These kind of experiences can spark ideas and challenge some people to a different way of thinking.

However, it also depends on the individual and how they receive the game.  One person may go into shooter and think, "I'm going to be sneaky and do unexpected things in order to gain an advantage." while another person may think, "Headshots for everybody!" while running around being trigger happy.  Either way, games are fun most of the time.

To know whether video games will improve the player, you will need to know what type the player is.

Some are stubborn, we call them retards or "tards", who purposely not learn from their mistakes, you see a lot of these shit-heads in multiplayer, either they do this on purpose or they're just too incredibly stupid to compete, and because of them the entire team fails.

Games such as HoN / Dota2 will have heavy penalties from simple mistakes, you have egotistic morons who think they're pros and will try to take on 5 on their own without realising they're feeding continuously, LoL teams who move to HoN are like this, they think they're good, only to selfishly destroy themselves and their team.

Nonetheless, if you're incredibly stupid, I think video-games will only waste your time.

And last note, I feel dumber after playing games such as Saints Row 4, these games are ridiculous... but fun  : )

Games such as CoD only improves spatial recognition skills, however, depending on the player, it can be extremely negative. At least Battlefield multiplayer requires more tactical development and does not approach the game with a run-shoot-run moronic approach.

Games such as Total War help significantly depending on the player, if players consistently avoid multiplayer to avoid competition, or, alternatively, spend a large amount to unlock all DLCs to gain an unfair advantage, as well as consistently fighting against easy difficulty AI, this impedes any development of intelligence, for some (I know them), they only watch the infantries engage and enjoy the blood-shed, if you have blood pack DLCs...

However, for more intelligent players, they develop very precise algorithmic approaches, and can assist in fields such as decision mathematics, I would say that Total War games have assisted me in these type of fields, as algorithms that is intended to shorten distances given a particular objective, can be applied on a continued basis in Total War as strategy.

Games that improve reaction time doesn't improve intelligence, you might as well play sports.

My experience: it depends on how you define "smart".  I am a Mechanical Engineer with a BS working toward an MS.  I love playing video games, but they have never directly helped me to pass a Partial Differential Equations or Heat Transfer exam.  It has, however, helped to ignite my creativity, understand 3-dimensional spatial relationships (valuable when creating 3-D part models in SolidWorks or another CAD package), gain a greater interest in physics, etc.  It also has greatly increased my hand-eye coordination.  I use them for leisure and a stress reliever.  But video gaming alone would never have qualified me to become an engineer; it still takes hard work, studying, patience, and academic aptitude.  I agree with this video; I have known people who let video games ruin their lives and have achieved relatively little outside of graduating from high school.  Peace.

Hang on, because this is a tiny bit complex: Video games reinforce the illusion of perfect information. In video games, the stats of your opponent allows you to make perfect decisions. In real life, you will never ever have perfect information. I have noticed in my students that play a lot of video games of this type, that they appear ill equipped to handle decision making in imperfect information scenarios, mostly due to their overconfidence in the information presented to them.

I’m a good example of video games helping someone with dyslexia becoming a better reader. When I graduated grade school (5th grade) I was reading below a 3rd grade reading level. Then I got a Nintendo 64 (my first console) over that summer break. I started playing a bunch of the N64 adventure games (Banjo-Kazooie, Super Mario 64, Donkey Kong 64, etc.) none of which have any voice acting so all the dialogue has to be read. By the time I started 6th grade I was reading at about a 5th grade reading level and by the time I graduated middle school (8th grade) I was reading at a 12+ (college) reading level.

Look at the little girl who had half her brain removed to stop seizures. She was young enough for her brain to form new connections. I think that if video games can strengthen the brain then that would make you more intelligent depending on how you used it, and if the brain can learn to rewire itself or strengthen or use different synapses then that is intelligence.

I know for a fact it helps increase reaction time, even when playing sports games like mlb2k13. You have a split second to swing, take a ball or fight off a pitch until you get yours with all the different speeds and breaks on the ball. But it is a video game. It must do something to the connections in your brain over time and make them faster. In real life, you cannot even see a fastball once you decide to swing where the ball would be 15' from the plate at 95mph. You need to start swinging when you can't see the ball. But those are trained professionals and like a racecar driver, over time the ball probably seems slowed down enough to pick it up and then they get into these zones where they can actually see the threads on the ball and pick up the spin. That's amazing, they're above average and deserve what they get and work hard but they don't deserve the amount of money their agents demand.

Baseball ruined all pro sports, really the New York Yankees ruined all professional sports. I know that's off topic, I just wanted to put it out there.

So is a higher reaction time considered higher intelligence? Anyways video games do something to help the connections in our brains. It may help early onset Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, multiple sclerosis, etc. patients could strengthen neural pathways in their brains and help slow down their symptoms or prolong the movement of their bodies before they become "stuck". I don't know if there have been studies done or even thought about, but if it's something that hasn't been looked into, it definitely should.

Also another thought, just moving your hands and arms around to play a video game causes muscle memory and could help a lot of people like amputees remember how to use lost limbs so prosthetics would be easier to use by activating those parts of the brain that won't nee active anymore. Plus many more ideas that I don't want to write a novel about. I'm not a doctor, these are just ideas from what we're told from the mainstream medical information that is available to the general population.

There's even more good points to video games other than memory progression.  It also can fundamentally lessen arthritis in the fingers and hand-eye coordination.  When using more recent gaming accessories, like Kinect, Sony Move and Wii Fit, it also increases the burning desire to exercise, in this case Cardio movement, Yoga and dance.  There was a study I recall of if playing video games actually can help you lose weight.  The results were rather mixed, but there was significant weight decrease by playing the games that involved dance, like Dance Dance Revolution, Just Dance, and other games that involved complete body movement.  

To add to this positive testimony, I have played video games most of my life, including DDR and Wii Fit, as an exercise routine.  I didn't change my diet, but after playing DDR for about an hour a day, 5 days a week, my weight has decreased by 20 lbs every two weeks, that's about a 10 lbs loss a week or around a pound a day, including being at work that involved physical labor, and walking to work, or just walking in general due to lack of a vehicle.

Something random also: First Person Shooters WILL improve your aim. Didn't used to play many of them, mostly a strategy and RPG gamer. Bought a gun, went shooting a few times and wasn't a very good shot. Started playing FPS games, didn't go shooting again for like a year. Go back, and suddenly at the same range my cluster was a lot tighter even though I hadn't actually practiced with a real gun.

And after practicing with a real gun extensively, my FPS aiming skills got better as well.
So I can see why the military was looking into an FPS like training simulator for new recruits: It does have effective results.
But I will say: I got better at shooting a whole lot faster by actually shooting than I did through playing FPS games.

More than just make you "smarter", I've found that you can learn more about yourself too. Playing a game like Mass Effect can teach you more about who you are and what your personal values are. It may not be "Smarter" as measurable tests on attention and so forth, but I find it a life-enriching experience, and I find inspiration to make my own life better.

Case in point: Persona 4 was a game that for some reason made studying really fun for me, and as a result, I found myself studying harder and got significantly better grades
